{{Infobox software | name = Life360 | logo = Logo_for_Life360_App.png | logo size = 250px | developer = Life360 | latest release version = | latest release date = | programming language = | operating system = [[iOS]]
[[Android (operating system)|Android]]
[[Windows Phone]] | genre = [[Location-based service]] | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]] | website = {{URL|http://www.life360.com/}} }} '''Life360''' is a family networking [[Application software|app]] released in 2008. It is a [[location-based service]] designed to allow friends or family members to share their location with each other and communicate with each other. ==History== Life360 was founded by [[Chris Hulls]] and Alex Haro and has received a total of $90 million in funding since its launch, including funding from both [[Facebook]] and [[Google]].{{cite news | last =Perez | first =Sarah | coauthors = | title =Life360, The Family Locator With More Users Than Foursquare, Raises A $10 Million Series B | newspaper =Tech Crunch| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =10 July 2013| url = https://techcrunch.com/2013/07/10/life360-the-family-locator-with-more-users-than-foursquare-raises-10-million-series-b/ | accessdate =22 October 2013 }} The app was initially released in 2008 in the Android marketplace.{{cite news | last =Perez | first =Sarah | coauthors = | title =Life360, A Family Networking App With more Users Than Foursquare, Is Now Headed For Cars, Smart Home Systems | newspaper =Tech Crunch | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =26 April 2013 | url = https://techcrunch.com/2013/04/26/life360-a-family-networking-app-with-more-users-than-foursquare-is-now-headed-for-cars-smart-home-systems/ | accessdate =22 October 2013 }} The first funding for Life360 came in the form of a $275,000 grant as a winner of Google's 2008 [[Android Developer Challenge]].{{cite news | last =Siegler | first =MG | coauthors = | title =Android Developer Challenge I winners – nary a big name in sight | newspaper =Venture Beat | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =28 August 2008 | url = https://venturebeat.com/2008/08/28/android-developer-challenge-i-winners-nary-a-big-name-in-sight/ | accessdate =22 October 2013 }} Additional funding included $5.5 million in a Series A round, $17 million in a Series B round, and $50 million in a Series C round. Life360 entered into an agreement with [[BMW]] in 2013 to integrate the location services of Life360 with the navigation in BMW automobiles. The same year, Life360 surpassed [[Foursquare]] in the number of registered users with 34 million and reached more than 40 million registered users the same year. Life360 also saw an increase in user registration following the announcement from Google that they would be shutting down their [[Google Latitude]] platform in August 2013.{{cite news | last =Riddell | first =Lindsay | coauthors = | title =Life360 goes after Google Latitude’s evicted users | newspaper =San Francisco Business Times | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =24 July 2013 | url =http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/blog/2013/07/life360-goes-after-google-latitudes.html | accessdate =22 October 2013 }} It was announced in 2013 that Life360 would be adding global support for its app which would include support in languages other than English and international SMS.{{cite news | last =Fitchard | first =Kevin | coauthors = | title =Life360’s App Knows Where Your Children Are | newspaper =Bloomberg Businessweek| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =3 July 2013| url = http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2013-07-03/life360-s-app-knows-where-your-children-are | accessdate =22 October 2013 }} The announcement came after downloads of the Life360 app increased internationally, even though the app was only available in English. In 2016, Life360 added a feature that enables smartphones to detect when people are in a car crash and automatically contacts emergency response.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gpsbusinessnews.com/Life360-Adds-Car-Crash-Detection-and-Automatic-Emergency-Call-to-App_a5929.html|title=Life360 Adds Car Crash Detection and Automatic Emergency Call to App|last=Privat|first=Ludovic|website=GPS BUSINESS NEWS|access-date=2016-06-06}} In February 2016, Life360 acquired the private messaging application and Y Combinator grad Couple based in Mountain View.{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/02/12/family-app-life360-acquires-couple-a-private-messaging-app-for-two/|title=Family App Life360 Acquires Couple, A Private Messaging App For Two – TechCrunch|website=techcrunch.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-16}} At [[Consumer Electronics Show|CES]] in January 2018, [[The ADT Corporation|ADT]] announced ADT Go in partnership with Life360. ADT Go connects and protects families outside the home, utilizing ADT's expansive security infrastructure.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/adt-unveils-apps-doorbells-and-more-at-ces-2018/|title=ADT unveils apps, doorbells and more at CES 2018|date=2018-01-08|work=CNET|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://pando.com/2014/05/14/life360-continues-to-prioritize-utility-in-its-family-social-network-raises-50m-from-adt-to-tackle-the-connected-home/|title=Prioritizing utility in its family social network, Life360 raises $50M from ADT to tackle the connected home|date=2014-05-14|work=Pando|access-date=2018-04-15|language=en-gb}} ==Features== Life360 is both a web and [[mobile app]]lication and was referred to as a "family-oriented private social network" by [[Bloomberg Businessweek]]. The app is a social network for families and differentiates itself in this way as it is not based around peer groups or professional networks such as [[Find My Friends]] and [[LinkedIn]]. It allows users to share locations, group message, and call for roadside assistance.{{cite web|url=http://www.theappzine.com/reviews/life360-app-stay-connected-family-and-friends|title=Life360 app stay connected with family and friends|publisher=theappzine.com, Retrieved 24 July 2015}} It has four main features which include location sharing, circles, places, and premium. ===Locations sharing=== The main feature of the app is location sharing. Users can open the app and see where other members are instantly. Users can choose to share or not to share their location with any particular circle at any particular time.{{cite news | last =Dickinson | first =Boonsri | coauthors = | title =Life360 turns your smartphone into a lifeline | newspaper =CNet | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =20 June 2011 | url = http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20071791-1/life360-turns-your-smartphone-into-a-lifeline/| accessdate =22 October 2013 }} ===Circles=== Circles is the app’s newest feature, released on September 3, 2013. Circles allows users to create separate groups within the app, e.g. “caregivers,” “extended family,” and “John’s baseball team.” Users’ location is only visible to those who are also in the circle, and members in “caregivers” cannot see the location of users in “extended family,” unless they are also in that circle.{{cite news | last =Fitchard | first =Kevin | coauthors = | title =Life360 moves beyond the nuclear family, adding social features to its tracking app | newspaper =Gigaom | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =4 September 2013 | url = http://gigaom.com/2013/09/04/life360-moves-beyond-the-nuclear-family-adding-social-features-to-its-tracking-app/| accessdate =22 October 2013 }} ===Places=== Life360 allows users to create geofences that alert them when another enters or leaves another location.{{cite news | last =Yeung | first =Ken | coauthors = | title =Life360, the location app for families, nears 25m users; adds geo-fencing feature and local crime data | newspaper =The Next Web | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =18 December 2012 | url = https://thenextweb.com/insider/2012/12/18/life360-to-hit-25-million-users-adds-geo-fencing-feature/| accessdate =22 October 2013 }} ===Premium=== Life360 operates as a [[Freemium|freemium app]], and users can pay for extra features. These extra features include: stolen phone insurance, access to a live advisor 24/7, unlimited creation of “Places," and emergency roadside assistance. Users have identified some problems such as signal drop and inaccurate location reporting. ==Awards and recognition== Life360 has received multiple awards including funding as winner of both Google Android Developer Challenge and Facebook fbFund.{{cite news | last =Kincaid | first =Jason | coauthors = | title =Facebook Names First Class of fbFund REV, Its New Incubator | newspaper =Tech Crunch | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =28 May 2009 | url = https://techcrunch.com/2009/05/28/facebook-names-first-class-of-fbfund-rev-its-new-incubator/ | accessdate =22 October 2013 }} It received the People's Voice Award for Best Use of GPS or Location Technology at the 2012 [[Webby Awards]].{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Best use of GPS or Location Technology | work = | publisher =Webby Awards | date =2012 | url =http://winners.webbyawards.com/2012/mobile-apps/mobile-apps-features-categories-all-devices/best-use-of-gps-or-location-technology | format = | doi = | accessdate =28 October 2013}} The same year it was announced as the Gold Seal Winner at the Mom's Choice Awards and also received the Reader's Choice Award from [[About.com]] as the Coolest Parenting Teens Gadget Winner.{{cite news | last =Witmer | first =Denise | coauthors = | title =Coolest Parenting Teens Gadget Winner: Life360 Family Locator | newspaper =About.com | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =2012 | url = http://parentingteens.about.com/od/ReadersChoiceAwards/ss/2012-Readers-Choice-Award-Winners_7.htm| accessdate =22 October 2013 }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.life360.com/ Life360 Homepage] [[Category:GPS navigation software]]

[[File:Maravi Kingdom map c. 1650s.svg|thumb|The Maravi Kingdom at its greatest extent in the 17th century.]] '''Maravi''' was a kingdom which straddled the current borders of Malawi, Mozambique, and Zambia, in the 16th century. The present-day name "[[Malawi|Maláŵi]]" is said to derive from the [[Chewa language|Chichewa]] word "malaŵí", which means "flames".
At its greatest extent, the state included territory from the Tonga and [[Tumbuka people]]'s areas in the north to the [[Shire River|Lower Shire]] in the south, and as far west as the [[Luangwa River|Luangwa]] and [[Zambezi]] river valleys. Maravi's rulers belonged to the Mwale [[Serer maternal clans|matriclan]] and held the title [[Kalonga]]. They ruled from [[Manthimba]], the secular/administrative capital, and were the driving force behind the state's establishment. Meanwhile, the patrilineal Banda clan, which traditionally provided healers, sages and metallurgists, took care of religious affairs from their capital [[Mankhamba]] near [[Nthakataka]].
After contact with the [[Portugal|Portuguese]], trade intensified. It included such items as beads of the [[Khami]] type and [[China|Chinese]] [[porcelain]] imported via Portuguese intermediaries. In the 19th century, the state declined and the Maravi were frequently raided by their neighbours the [[WaYao|Yao]] and captured for sale as [[slavery|slaves]]. [[David Livingstone]] visited Lake Nyasa in 1859, and other [[Protestantism|Protestant]] missionaries soon followed.
The Maravi Confederacy was founded by the Bantu people immigrating into the valley of the Shire River (flowing out of Lake Nyassa) around 1480 AD. It prospered into the late 18th century, extending to reach what is now belonging to Zambia and Mozambique. In the 19th century the neighboring Yao raided on them, selling captive Maravi on the slave markets of Kilwa and Zanzibar. In the 1860s, Islam was introduced into the region through contact with Swahili slave traders. The region was visited by David Livingstone and stations were set up by Protestant missionaries in 1873. A British consul was also sent there in 1883.
Beginning as early as the thirteenth century, the first signs of a large-scale migration of related clans entered the region of Lake Malawi. Traditional accounts indicate that these people originated in the [[Congo Basin]] to the west of [[Lake Mweru]], in an area that subsequently formed part of the Luba Kingdom. The movement continued during the succeeding two or three centuries, but it appears certain that by the sixteenth century the main body of these people, known collectively as the Maravi, were settled in the Shire River valley and over a wide area lying generally west and southwest of Lake Malawi, including parts of present-day Zambia and Mozambique. The first (colonial) historical account of the Maravi was by Gaspar Boccaro, a Portuguese man who traveled through their territory in 1616. The picture presented in the 1660s by Father Manuel Barretto, a Jesuit priest, was of a strong, economically active confederation that swept an area from the coast of Mozambique between the Zambezi River and the bay of Quelimane for several hundred miles into the mainland. An account from the following century implied that the western limits of the confederation were near the Luangwa River and that it extended on the north to the Dwangwa River. <ref>https://www.britannica.com/topic/Maravi-Confederacy</ref>
"Maravi" is therefore a general name of the peoples of Malawi, Zambia, Mozambique and the eastern part of Zimbabwe. The [[Chewa language]], which is also referred to as Nyanja, Chinyanja or Chichewa, and is spoken in southern and central Malawi, in Zambia and to some extent in Mozambique, is the main language that emerged from this empire.
==References== <references />
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060109071410/http://www.axisgallery.com/exhibitions/maravi/ Maravi culture] *[http://www.zum.de/whkmla/region/southafrica/maravi.html History of Maravi]
